conbody.p: NCC CNF includes a powerful, flexible, and high-performance Agile Rule Technology (ART) Rule Engine. This enables customization of NCC logic and flows without requiring any code changes. Rules can be used for customization of existing services and flows and can even be used for creating additional new use cases.

The rule engine consists of various components that include rules, rule sets, source contexts, and result contexts. The Rule Engine evaluates the rules and returns results as the following figure shows.

fig.title: Evaluation of rules by Rule Engine

conbody.p: Rules are used to customize the NCC behaviors when certain events occur. Rules can be used for many things, including sending and customizing notifications, generating event logs, modifying session parameters, defining system policy, and for making customized charging decisions.

The Rule Engine operates in a simple input and output concept. The input is the data available for an invocation along with a set of rules to be invoked. The output is a result returned from the invocation. The Rule Engine implements an event-driven, forward-chaining rule evaluation algorithm using production style rules on invocation. When required, the NCC requests that the Rule Engine executes a particular Trigger using an interface available to the NCC.

All rules in the rule group that make up the Trigger are evaluated by the appropriate rule engines as their conditions are matched. A top-level rule group is generated from any profile or policy that exists. In each group, the first rule (in the order of precedence) whose conditions are met is executed. The actions specified in the rule are returned to the NCC application, where the appropriate steps are performed for the action.

After the application plugins have been sequenced, the rules and messages are evaluated and invoked by the system to process the specific functionality in the sequence of, and by, the installed application plugins. That is, rules are written such that as they cascade through the system the rule whose conditions are matched first is executed offering an order of precedence.

In the Charging application, when a trigger occurs, such as a message arriving at the CHF, the associated set of rules from the profiles configured are evaluated. The rules, with access to all of the data available, determine the service, rating, and charging for the device, group, and account. NCC then takes the appropriate action as the following figure shows.

Rules are organized into (potentially large) groups called Triggers. All triggers are pre-defined in NCC and are evaluated by the appropriate rule engine. Although the contents of Triggers can be defined, new Triggers cannot be introduced.

A rule group is a set of rules associated with a trigger that may be associated with a rule system version. Each rule group contains one or more groups of conditions and associated actions. When an event happens in the system, the corresponding Trigger is invoked, and then all rule groups that belong to the Trigger are evaluated and the Rule Groups are executed in an order of precedence.

A rule belongs to a rule group and is built from the options available in the rule conditions and actions. Triggers determine when the associated rule tables are analyzed and as message processing flows are executed in NCC, specific Triggers are applied.
See the respective application user guides for more information about their specific rule engines.
